5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Great fast android phone
allReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on October 26, 2024
allReviews.body: I have had this phone for a month. I had an android Motorola g 100 before this, which I liked for the almost pure android, SD card slot and headphone plug. My new Pixel 9 pro has pure Android but no SD card slot and no headphone jack (which I do miss). To make up for these missing items I got the new pixel with 512gb and a separate Bluetooth receiver for my old Klipsch X-10 headphones that are great. So far,  I'm very happy with the tradeoffs.The Pixel 9 pro is a great phone. It takes time to set it up, which is important. This version of Android gives you a lot of control and if you take the time to set it up,  you will benefit. As someone else said, initially, the battery runs down pretty quickly; however, the software learns how you work and over about 2 days  the battery life lasts much longer. I also installed a toolbox app which seems to add even more. I have never run below 40% after my heaviest phone use days. I also like the size of the 9 pro. I do not play games on my phone so I can not comment on its game play use.The bottom line is that the Pixel 9 pro simply works flawlessly, is fast  and is well made. It's expensive but it's a premium phone and worth it.

allReviews.title:
4.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Great device, mediocre phone
allReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 6, 2025
allReviews.body: PROS: Great battery life - I can literally use this phone for nearly two days straight without charging it assuming I am not watching movies or playing games constantly, and is a welcome improvement from my previous iPhone 12 mini. As far as processing speed, it does not seem to be any faster than an iPhone. Picture and camera quality is fantastic! I am able to take great quality pictures in all types of light, and the display quality is the best I have seen on a smartphone. The size is just a bit too large than what I am used to but does not seem to bother me when I have it in my pocket. The charging speed of the phone is very fast and gets a full battery in little more than an hour. The switch from iOS to Android seems to be a lot less painless than before as well.CONS: The call quality is a lot worse than an iPhone, especially for use in buildings. When making a call, the signal bars instantly drop and covert to either 3G or H+, and will not connect with the other line for up to 30 seconds even if I am outside. Note that I am referring to traditional cellular network use and not data calls (Signal, Whatsapp, etc.). These data calls are almost as good as an iPhone but not quite there yet. If I am on a call, I will have to often go outside where I did not have to previously do this with my iPhone mini.VERDICT: If you are looking for a portable computer and mostly data calls, this is one of the best Android phones you can purchase. However if you are still regularly using the cellular network for calls then I would recommend sticking to an iPhone.

allReviews.title:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Pixel 9 Pro XL is worth the hype
allReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2024
allReviews.body: I've had the Pixel 9 Pro XL for a week, and after countless hours of testing, I am quite happy with my purchase. To be clear, I am a regular person (not a professional reviewer) and I paid for the phone with my own money. No handouts or compensation here.I would venture to say that the majority of complaints about this 9th gen Pixel are from people who don't have one (Verified Purchase?). This is a great phone. Everything just works, and works well. It is responsive and fast; while Samsung and Apple flagships may win benchmarks, in real world use, this phone is able to handle everything I've thrown at it.And real world use is where this phone shines. I come from Samsung and did not like their bloated UI and baked-in Samsung apps. This is the purest possible Android experience and it shows. Everything just works, intuitively, and works well.It's been a few years since I used an iPhone as my daily driver, but anyone who is stuck on iPhone as the "just works" phone, check this phone out. If you prefer the Google ecosystem (Gmail, Docs, Drive, Calendar, etc), the Pixel is the way to go. They are all deeply integrated without the bloat or workarounds on other phones.I've heard of problems attaining the fastest charging levels without buying the expensive Google charger, but I charge on a wireless charger at night while I sleep. Even using a third-party (and cheap) wireless charger, it charges decently. It seems this phone requires the charger to bump voltage to get the 37 watt charging, so if you care about squeezing in your charges at the fastest charging speeds, perhaps get the official Google wired charger or be very thorough in your charger research.But I dont think you'll need it. For me, charging speeds don't matter with this big battery. It has lasted me all day, every day, and I have intensely used it from sunup to sundown. Never once have I risked needing to charge it between 5am and 10pm. As long as the phone lasts all day and only needs to be charged at night, I don't think it matters if it takes 90 minutes to charge. But that's a personal decision for you to make for yourself.The camera is amazing. It takes some of the best photos I've seen come from a phone. And while there are plenty of choices out there for post-processing your photos, having features like Video Boost or Zoom Enhance baked right into the Photos app makes it a simple joy to take photos and edit them. I challenge anyone to find a simpler and easier workflow for taking the best possible photos. If you want to take amazing photos and be able to edit and enhance them in a few seconds without switching between an array of apps, this phone is for you. Of course third-party editing apps are a Play Store away, but you probably won't them them.I know Google hypes the AI, but generally that's not why I got the phone, so I'll leave the in-depth AI reviews to others. Some of it is fun -- Magic Editor is a fun toy and Zoom Enhance stretches the boundaries of what's possible on a phone camera, but things like Gemini Live feel a little half baked. Don't get me wrong; Gemini Live is a leap forward for Google, but the AI as a whole feels disjointed. Gemini Live doesn't communicate directly with regular Gemini, and while it's great for chatting, it can't do even basic tasks (which requires switching to the other Gemini).It's also quite perplexing that there are still basic Google Assistant functions that Gemini can't call up. It feels like it should be a basic ask to relay all Assistant functions, but it's not that simple. These are minor annoyances that will hopefully improve in the future, but (to Google) if you're going to hype the AI so much, please have it more integrated and seemless than this. It feels like a miss that the feature you're hyping the most is the one with the most blemishes. But AI is quickly evolving. Maybe my comments will be moot in a week. And like I said, since I didn't get the phone for the AI, this isn't a ding for me.I'll update if any issues arise, but so far I'm very satisfied with my purchase. This is my first Pixel, and I can see why there are Pixel fans. This phone might not be everything to everyone, but it's not supposed to be. If you want a premium phone that feels great, looks great, and does what it does very well, give this newest Pixel a shot. If you're using an iPhone but not yet too deeply invested in their closed box, or if you're a Samsung owner who's tired of the bloat, I recommend checking out the Pixel 9 Pro XL.  It's great to have so much choice in the smartphone world, and I believe this is a choice worthy of your attention.

allReviews.title:
5.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Made the switch from Samsung to Google after 15 Years
allReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2025
allReviews.body: I have been using Samsung phones since they first came out, with the S4 being one of my most memorable experiences. I appreciated some of the more rugged, active-style Samsung models I could take to work with me, especially during my younger years working on the pipeline. However, as I grew older and focused on my education, my phone became essential for assisting me with schoolwork, alongside my laptop, throughout most of my college career. Now that I am finishing my education and starting my career, I rely on my phone to help me accomplish various goals throughout the day. Before switching to the Google Pixel 9 Pro XL, my last phone was the Samsung Galaxy S21.Simply put, the Pixel 9 Pro XL is exceptional. It receives regular and helpful updates from Google and tends to get updated Android versions faster than other phone variants. This is great if you prioritize updating your software efficiently and promptly.This phone charges relatively quickly. It also has a feature that allows it to charge slowly overnight, which helps extend battery life.Speaking of the battery, it lasts all day long. I can often get close to three-quarters of a second day if necessary, even with regular work and personal use. I have never had to enable power saver mode, and when the phone drops to 20%, it automatically shifts to a lower power mode, extending battery life significantly.The screen is clear and highly functional; I have experienced no sensitivity issues. The picture quality and resolution are excellent, and the videos play smoothly without any problems.The camera is user-friendly and takes stunning photos. You can see the attached pictures in my review. Although I'm not a professional photographer, the images have great detail, with a good balance of shadows, contrast, highlights, and other important elements. The "Add Me" function on the camera is fairly easy to use. When you take the first picture and then add yourself to a second one, if you position yourself correctly, it can be tough to tell that the picture wasn't taken in one shot.Overall, I highly recommend making the switch if you're considering it. I've heard positive feedback from others who transitioned from iPhones to this phone, and it does include some features that could facilitate the change. While I'm not an iPhone user myself, I suggest talking to someone who is to explore that perspective further.Lastly, if you get it, get a case. With a screen protector, fingerprint functionality will be subpar. But I want an unblemished screen, so I suffer the effects.

allReviews.title:
4.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    This Is A Nice Phone Except For A Few Important Things
allReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2025
allReviews.body: Make no mistake, this is a very fine phone very fine piece of technology. But as usual or typical of all phones, it comes down to whether or not the phone works for each individual. For me, it simply did not.First, I have a Subaru with Bluetooth. Although this phone connects easily with Bluetooth in my vehicle, the voice/sound quality is atrocious. For the first couple of minutes the other party is almost unintelligible, and then it gets better to being able to understand one word in eight. The other phones I've owned had no such problem with this car. The technician from Google cannot figure out why this was happening either. I make a lot of phone calls from my vehicle so this is extremely important to have functioning properly and with clarity. In my to buy another vehicle so that the sound/voice quality from this phone will work better?Although the face recognition software and hardware works fine, the fingerprint recognition software and hardware need some work. If you have the slightest moisture on your finger, if you have the slightest dirt on your finger, the fingerprint scanner will either not read or take several tries before it will read. This is not only annoying, but sometimes in my line of work it is critical to have it work immediately.The sound volume is not nearly as high as with other phones and neither is the haptic feedback. Also, quite annoying. If I'm away from my phone more than a few feet before I realize it's ringing, many times, the caller has hung up! The ring volume and other uses for a higher volume in noisy areas is not as good as with other phones I've owned.It is not until we get another phone that we realize that some of the small things, such as volume, caller voice/sound quality, and other things, are important. This phone, although produced by a reputable company, still needs much improvement. The chipset is a major drawback for me. I do a lot of video calls and this phone freezes a bit more than other phones that I owned. These are things you buy a new phone for to help eliminate such problems.This was supposed to replace my Galaxy Z Flip 6, but it simply does not measure up. Perhaps the next Google generation will be better.

    It's a solid phone but the sound controller is subpar
allReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2024
allReviews.body: It's a fast phone for general use. There hasn't been any hiccups going between apps. Something worth mentioning is the vapor chamber cooling. This means performance will be substained longer periods of the time. The screen is probably the best I've ever used. The motions in the UI is smooth and picture quality is amazing. The adaptive brightness is way too aggressive. I've seen it auto change it below 25 percent in a moderately lit room which doesn't make sense. The battery life is probably my favorite as I can easily last and entire 9-5 work day with 85 percent left to spare.The reason why it is getting 4 stars is because of the price and sound controller. Starting price of 999 USD for performance and build quality is outrageous compared to the competition. The entry level Samsung S24 has all these features and performance is much better.The way the Pixel handles sound is very bad. I couldn't probably sync my Jabra earbuds and Galaxy Watch without problems. I needed to removed my buds from the list of previous sync devices that my Google account had stored, and then I needed to factory reset my watch. Furthermore, there is a latency for how the audio is passed from Bluetooth devices and sometimes doesn't work at all. For example, the audio for Google Assistant will flip between my buds and speakers when called. And there are times when my music doesn't when play at all when Google Assistant is fine with my query. It's clearly buggy and needs more work through patching.

    Great phone, but still big
allReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2024
allReviews.body: I finally upgraded from my Pixel 4a to a Pixel 9 Pro. I loved my 4a, which still had snappy performance along with a physical fingerprint reader that is super reliable and easy to unlock by touch as well as a headphone jack, all in a compact, lightweight, durable body. Unfortunately the battery was getting worn out quickly and are a pain to replace on that model, so here we are.The Pixel 9 Pro feels solid, but even the "smaller" body is still too big for my preference. It is hefty, which I understand given the materials used, but I also dont feel confident that the weight translates to durability; the materials still seem delicate enough to necessitate a case, which only adds weight and volume. I also miss the physical fingerprint reader on the back, which could be used by muscle memory and swiped down to bring the notification shade down with one hand. And dont get me started on the removal of headphone jacks and Micro SD cards from phones that cost nearly $1000.That said, the phone functions well and has been reliable for me so far. Calls are fine, and the built-on Pixel call screening is still the standout feature for me. Cameras are great, although the post-processing has gone a few steps too far into being over processed and I wish that could be dialed back a nudge.

So this review is after a only few days of use, and coming from Sony.Set up was SEAMLESS, copied everything over from my old phone, just up to me to set up as I want it. The screen is amazing. Super bright and contrasty. The software is excellent, very clean version of Android.For me, the camera on a phone is very important and this one has not disappointed, at least in the very limited use I have put it through. Have used the add me feature, and it worked very well. Macro focus is an outstanding feature and one I will use frequently for close-ups. Telephoto images are bit soft, but I would love to use it with some kind of stability (tri or monopod) to see if the softness is due to user movement rather than lens quality. I miss the Sony software as it really feels like you are using an SLR camera in a phone. So I am in a bit of a learning curve here. But getting there quickly. I look forward to exploring and learning more of the camera software/hardware.Charging lasted easily over a day with very heavy use. Charge with the 45w Google charge "brick" was 5% to 75% in 45 minutes. Not bad at all. I have found the speed of the phone to be quick and responsive. Of all the devices in my house (computers, iPads, phones, etc), this has by FAR has the fastest Speedtest results on our home wifi. I mean it is not even close! Face and fingerprint recognition has been flawless.A lot of reviewers out there have talked about build quality and aesthetic. I remember handling an earlier pixel (no idea which model, maybe 4 years ago?) and thought it felt lightweight and "toylike." That is NOT the case here. The phone is gorgeous and substantive in design and feel. Coming from the Sony 1 III the phone does not feel too big, nor heavy.For these reasons, I give 5 stars.

    Pure Google Perfection
allReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2024
allReviews.body: My Pixel 9 Pro XL was already a fantastic phone, but the Android 15 update has made it even better.  While it's not a radical overhaul, Android 15 brings a noticeable improvement in performance and responsiveness.  Everything feels snappier and smoother, from launching apps to scrolling through web pages.The updated interface is clean and modern, with subtle refinements that enhance the user experience. I appreciate that Google didn't go overboard with changes, instead focusing on polishing the existing Android experience.While there aren't a ton of new features, the ones that are included are well-implemented.  The enhanced privacy controls give me more granular control over my data, which is always welcome.But honestly, the best thing about having a Pixel is being on the bleeding edge of Android updates.  It's a great feeling to know that I'm running the latest and greatest version of Android as soon as it's available.

Maybe revision 2 or 3 will be customer ready, the current release is not ready. Do not buy if you expect to use this phone as a part of a larger Google product environment, it does not integrate.As a one off device, it is a flagship brand-name cell phone meant for 2024, it has the same computing capability as all flagship phones, nothing surprising there, every year pixel modules on the phone improve ever so slightly, nothing worthy of note.I was looking for a device to replace my previous multipurpose cell phone, I was mislead to believe this device was essentially an upgraded version of the 8 pro, it is not. After days are of fruitless attempts, this phone will not connect to my Google wifi mesh, my pixel watch, or the other Google home accessories that I've purchased directly from Google.Avoid this bad product, until Google fixes their laziness.

    Don't fall for the hype.
criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on March 1, 2025
criticalReviews.body: First off, I have been a happy owner of Pixels going back to the first model. However, the battery life of my Pixel4a 5G is better and the rear fingerprint scanner is far superior than any of these crappy screen fingerprint scanners. The one on the Pixel 9 is no better than the crappy one on my old Samsung that's a few years old. Seriously, none of these newer phones are worth the prices unless you feel the need to have the latest and "greatest" phone for nit picking and bragging purposes. Sure the camera is better but it's a phone! Wish I did not purchase and just installed LineageOS on my Pixel4a 5G, instead. Bet I could get a few more years out of it with nothing more than the cost of a replacement battery when the time comes.

criticalReviews.body: Compré el Google Pixel 9 Pro con altas expectativas, ya que su diseño, tamaño más compacto y las características de su cámara realmente me llamaron la atención. Debo admitir que las fotos y los videos tienen colores muy reales y una excelente estabilización, pero, lamentablemente, no fue suficiente para convencerme de quedármelo.El mayor problema fue el sonido. Utilizo audífonos todo el tiempo para escuchar podcasts, y aunque esperaba una gran experiencia con los Pixel Buds, no me convenció la calidad del sonido espacial en comparación con lo que ofrece el ecosistema de Apple. Esto fue un gran punto débil para mí.Al final, después de probarlo durante una semana, decidí devolverlo. Aunque es un buen dispositivo en algunos aspectos, no cubrió mis necesidades ni cumplió con mis expectativas generales. Siento que sigue estando por debajo de lo que ofrecen otros equipos.

criticalReviews.body: I honestly think the Pixel 8's rounded edges made it the more comfortable option, but the 9 Pro bezel polished metal is easy to grip most of the time. I do not use a case, and I've only noticed a difficult grip in excessively dry conditions. I do not have very large hands, and the camera bar adds an ergonomic hold that makes this feel secure in my hand and easy to hold and use.Although this has some more memory and some exclusive AI features, I don't benefit from them much to say they're worth the upgrade. Gemini is great at some conversational AI, but isn't always accurate and I don't need to (re)write emails/texts in new tones or such, so I don't use LLM stuff much.  I love the camera though, and I've never experienced slowness or sluggishness (not that I had much issue with that on the Pixel 8 either).

criticalReviews.title:
2.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Does not integrate in a straight forward manner
criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on November 29, 2024
criticalReviews.body: I purchased this phone to replace a pixel 8 pro, as it seemed like a one for one swap with all of the interconnected Google devices. I.e. nest, watch, wifi mesh, cameras, etc... I was wrong.This phone may have great ram, great refresh rate, and on and on, but if it does not integrate, I regret purchasing this.I am leaving this review in the event there are folks out there that are looking to purchase another piece to their already fragile Google "smart home", without making things worse. This phone does not support the same thing as the pixel 8 pro. Avoid this rubbish until the QC folks at Google do their job and integrate this insanely expensive telephone with some general use capability. Maybe revision 2 or 3 will be customer ready, the current release is not ready. Do not buy if you expect to use this phone as a part of a larger Google product environment, it does not integrate.As a one off device, it is a flagship brand-name cell phone meant for 2024, it has the same computing capability as all flagship phones, nothing surprising there, every year pixel modules on the phone improve ever so slightly, nothing worthy of note.I was looking for a device to replace my previous multipurpose cell phone, I was mislead to believe this device was essentially an upgraded version of the 8 pro, it is not. After days are of fruitless attempts, this phone will not connect to my Google wifi mesh, my pixel watch, or the other Google home accessories that I've purchased directly from Google.Avoid this bad product, until Google fixes their laziness.

criticalReviews.body: There are a couple issues, some major some minor, my previous experience was an S21 Ultra, here's how this compares- My biggest issue is the fingerprint scanner - compared to what I had before this is EXTREMELY frustrating, I'm not sure if my phone is defective but I'm left using the code to unlock 90% of the time because it doesn't pick up my fingerprint- For a phone touted as an amazing camera phone something as simple as switching your camera from front to back or vice versa while recording should be a feature like it was on my S21 ultra- Video Boost is unusable - 1) I have to turn it on before i record each time and 2) when I do remember to turn it on it takes literally hours to process a video of a few secondsSmaller peeves- Navigation - I cannot change the order of the on screen navigation buttons so I was forced to use gestures to navigate which isn't that great- A bit duplicitous but navigation / touching the edges of the screen such as when i'm trying to record a voice note sometimes just doesn't work - as in my voice note just cuts off, it really feels as if I've a defective product- The launcher seems just very limiting in general and frustrating to useI've always changed phone brands in the past, oneplus, samsung and even a very old nexus device, this is by far the most frustrating experience I've had with a phone

criticalReviews.title:
1.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Terrible Bluetooth, apparent working as intended
criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on September 3, 2024
criticalReviews.body: I've had this phone for less than a week and spent most of this morning talking with the support people (to their credit, they're open 24/7), the local repair shop, etc.  I cannot get the phone to consistently pair with my Garmin watch, which, apparently is a known issue within a week of the phone being released. I know this because the repair guy's attitude is, "well it is a problem for everyone".  It also drops connections with HRMs (Morpheus brand) and several ear buds and the Heartmath sensor.My issue is that ALL of these work fine with a phone that was FAR less expensive and not very good and not very new.  They ALL work terribly with this Pixel (9 Pro, XL, the sage green/gray one). Shouldn't it be the other way around?I even factory reset my Garmin to get it to work with the phone at the repair place (that google sent me to!) and now I can't get my watch face back on because no amount of restarting devices will get the phone and the watch to talk to each other.If this is happening within a week, what's going to happen as we move into year 2 of owning this thing?No issues if they sold this phone for $200. But this is a $1200 phone. Google doesn't seem to care at all.

criticalReviews.title:
3.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Perspective of someone who had a Pixel 8
criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on October 11, 2024
criticalReviews.body: Performance - I went from a Pixel 7 Pro to a Pixel 8 because I wanted a smaller phone. Unfortunately that meant taking a cut in RAM from 12GB to 8GB. This introduced a pretty massive problem for me because it meant I couldn't run Google Maps + Spotify + V1Driver (radar detector app) simultaneously while driving because V1Driver would keep closing in the background. With the 9 Pro's 16GB, I haven't had any issues at all with my phone closing apps in the background.Size - I'm really glad Google introduced a slightly smaller pro phone. I'd love if Google made a Pixel Pro Mini that was even smaller (iPhone 13 mini size).Design - I'm a huge fan of the squared edges making a return. It makes installing tempered glass so much easier. I stuck to Sony Xperias for a long time almost exclusively for this reason.Fingerprint reader - Google has finally moved to an ultrasonic fingerprint reader and it is so much better than the optical readers of the last two generations. With the Pixel 7 Pro/8 my fingerprint worked about 65% of the time. With the 9 Pro, I have a near 100% hit rate with a Spigen Tempered glass.Complaints - here's what prevents this from being a perfect phone. It starts at 128GB (storage upgrades are insanely overpriced) and is non expandable. Yes, most phones haven't had a MicroSD card reader for a while but I will not stop complaining about it because of how critical it is to the longevity of your device.Final thoughts - I'm far from an average consumer and couldn't care any less about the "AI features". I only ever use AI when I'm coding/working and even that I do on my PC with GitHub Copilot. I'm pretty happy to have a phone that does almost everything I need. But if Google ever reintroduced expandable storage, or made repairability any easier, they'd get 5 stars, easily.

criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on February 17, 2025
criticalReviews.body: Good as long as picture quality isn't important to you. Picture quality is one of the most important features to me so I watched a lot of videos comparing the Pixel Pros 8/9 vs. Samsung S24/25. I found multuple videos saying that the Pixel was better and we needed two new phones so I went with the Pixel and my wife went with the Samsung, both the highest end models from both companies. The Pixel is way behind in camera quality compared to the Samsung. Colors aren't captured well and the clarity is terrible for a phone that cost over $1000. If you are someone that keeps their phone for years, definitely pay the extra for the Samsung, It's worth the cost difference spread out over 3-5 years because you will have thousands of pictures and hundreds of videos that you want to be as accurate as possible. If picture quality isn't that big of a deal to you, the Pixel is fine. It performs all other functions well

Now, you decide if you want to buy Pixel 9.----------------------------------------------------------------Thank you for contacting Google Support.This is Diana, I'll be assisting you today while the previous agent is currently out of office. I understand your Pixel 8 device is having a green screen issue. We apologized for the inconvenience this has caused you.I understand you purchased your device from T-Mobile in the US, but you're currently travelling in India and will be in Chicago in April. Your device's warranty expired on February 19, 2025. While your device was still under warranty when you first contacted us on February 12, 2025, the warranty is only valid in the country where you purchased the device (the US). Because you're currently in India, your device is considered outside of its original warranty coverage.This means that if you choose to have your device repaired in Chicago, there will be repair costs, as the warranty will have expired. However, since you're currently in India, you might want to consider having the device repaired there but it also has a repair cost. There are authorized repair centers in India, and repairing it there might be more convenient for you at this time.If you'd like to explore repair options in India, please let me know.Thank you for your continued support and being a valued member of the Pixel family.Best regards,DianaThe Google Support TeamGoogle Google Help Center© Google LLC, 1600 Amphitheatre Parkway, Mountain View, CA 94043 USA

criticalReviews.title:
3.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Amazon shipping sucks... Buy elsewhere
criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on August 29, 2024
criticalReviews.body: Great phone! I know because I bought 2, one from Amazon the other from best buy. The best buy one was delivered before the Amazon one even shipped and the arrival date keeps getting pushed.

criticalReviews.title:
1.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Worst phone I have ever owned.
criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on March 11, 2025
criticalReviews.body: The most expensive and worst phone I have ever purchased. I've never had an Android phone this buggy. It changes time zones to another country in the middle of the night and changes my clock with it. So I have alarms going off at the wrong time. It won't let me use Gemini AI because it thinks I'm in another country. Even though Google maps shows me exactly where I am. It's not any faster than my pixel 7 was. unless you need to talk to satellites in emergencies I would buy a used pixel 7 over this and save a ton of money.

criticalReviews.title:
2.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Software needs updating (immediately)
criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on November 23, 2024
criticalReviews.body: I just got this and expected a cutting edge device.Sadly, and confirmed by Google reps who I called, their current software build cannot support some simple features like having more than 1 favorite contact or assigning ringtones to individual contacts. (Except for third-party apps for some reason.)This is not just about those features. If they can't do features that we cracked in 1997, what other deficiencies does the software have? I spoke with the reps form my carrier and were unaware of these shortcomings and willing to take the phone back. TL:DR Stay away until they update the software.

criticalReviews.title:
1.0 out of 5 stars







  
    No compren
criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2024
criticalReviews.body: Compre el Google pixel hace 1 mes y estuve de viaje 17 días, al segundo día se congeló completamente, esos 15 días restantes estuve sin teléfono. No hay tiendas oficiales para hacer ningún tipo de reparación y el servicio en línea es súper deficiente, la única solución que me dieron era borrar todos los datos yo mismo o mandarme uno “nuevo” que en realidad es uno remanofacturado, pero si el problema no lo incluye la garantía, ellos te cobrarán el precio completo de un teléfono nuevo :) . Si tienes IPhone y estás pensado en cambiarte a Android al igual que hice yo, te recomiendo pensarlo dos veces, analiza los beneficios y la comodidad de tener IPhone.En lo personal considero uno de mis peores errores el haber cambiado a Android y el haber comprado este teléfono.

criticalReviews.title:
2.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Disappointed
criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on December 3, 2024
criticalReviews.body: Washed out color levels compared to Pixel 7. Returned the product.

criticalReviews.title:
1.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Terrible SIM slot location and terrible body design.
criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2024
criticalReviews.body: Terrible SIM slot location and terrible body design. The SIM slot is right next to the microphone hole, clearly creating an impression that the microphone hole is the SIM opener hole, but it is not !!! The SIM opener hole is highly obscure, it can be barely seen - it is located on the curved corner of the phone, is rather small, is on reflective surface, and given the curvature of the corner location can be barely seen in the glare of the silver mirror-like siding of the phone. What kind of a designer in a sound mind would design such a trap??? The first thing one does is pressing the pin into the microphone channel to open the SIM slot. Fortunately, placing the pin into the microphone hole does not damage the microphone, but it still leaves a bitter feeling, since the owner is still concerned that microphone waterproofing mesh could be broken, or the sound channel may be damaged and lead to sound distortion. This experience spoils the happy purchase. Terrible SIM slot location and terrible body design.

criticalReviews.title:
1.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Google blocks PPS Fast Charging unless you buy a Google USB C cable which doesn't come in the box.
criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2024
criticalReviews.body: This issue is present since Pixel 7 series. High end 3rd party wall chargers and PD cables that work on other Android phones and iPhones doesn't work on Pixel phones because they are not "official" Google products. The issue is when you charge your phone you will experience constant charger disconnects and reconnects. Fast charging only works with official Google cable which costs $20.To make matters worse they don't even allow the charger to slow charge. It makes the charger completely useless. Google should change this policy and release a software update to allow whatever cable we want to use. USB C standard is for everyone.

criticalReviews.title:
1.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    This Pixel 9 launch is $200 overpriced!
criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2024
criticalReviews.body: The Pixel 7 Pro, launched at $1000 with 256GB, is now overshadowed by the New Pixel 9 Pro XL at $1200, lacking significant upgrades to justify the higher price. The G4 processor falls short compared to rivals of the same year, with no notable battery improvements to justify the cost. While I appreciate my Pixel 7 Pro for its performance at its original price, Google's latest models seem overpriced considering the competition from Samsung and Apple in the same price bracket.

criticalReviews.title:
1.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    128 GB SSD
criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on August 24, 2024
criticalReviews.body: I agree with Neftaly Hernandez  that offering 128 GB on a smartphone this expensive is a travesty.  The only thing that is "smart" about this move is your wallet "smarting" from shelling out extra money to future proof the storage.  It is basically a marketing ploy of "bait and switch."  Offer a low price to get lookers, then show them the inadequacies of the storage and switch them out to what they really need.

criticalReviews.title:
1.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Does not come unlocked
criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on November 5, 2024
criticalReviews.body: I paid out the butt for this phone only to receive a locked phone that I had to PAY to have unlocked. Amazon was completely unhelpful and useless about it too when I complained, offering a partial refund. A partial refund? Excuse me? Completely unacceptable. Zero stars.The phone itself is good once you pay to have it usable.

criticalReviews.title: No cumple con las especificaciones
criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in Mexico on December 30, 2024
criticalReviews.body: La descripción indica 256 gb de almacenamiento interno, pero el equipo es de 128 gb. Ocultan los datos originales de la caja con etiquetas nuevas.
